intro: Peucedanum virgatum, commonly known as the common cow parsley, is a biennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots, parsley, and dill, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small white or greenish flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 1 to 2 meters, with a slender, hollow stem that is often hairy. Its leaves are alternate, pinnately divided, and have a mild, aromatic scent when crushed. The fruit is a dry, two-lobed schizocarp, typical of the Apiaceae family, and contains two small seeds.
